stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the stream blocking-out, modelling and test-placing assets for an Old-West themed level. The big task is hand-building a low-poly, N64-legal train (locomotive + 1 car) that will circle the stage on tracks every ~10 s. He also walks chat through the layout of each building in town, tweaks tumbleweed behaviour, and chats optimisation.

development_findings.summary: Level will include three ‘criminal’ NPC types (5-Goomba gang, a Snufit and a Shy Guy) that Mario hunts down; after capture they are shown in the sheriff’s jail.
Kaze added emulator detection: when running on emulator the game auto-unlocks 60 FPS and removes draw-distance limits.
development_findings.quote: I’m making it so that on emulator drawing distances are unlimited… and it defaults to 60 fps instead of 30.

development_findings.summary: Tumbleweeds are separate actors; he noticed both spawn simultaneously and plans to stagger their spawn for variety.

Town buildings planned: sheriff’s office, hat store, random houses, ‘Big Iron’ gun shop, hotel (name TBD), tumbleweed store, chained Chain-Chomp pen, Unagi-oil salesman, saloon, and bank with large gold bars outside.
Bank scenario: player arrives after a robbery; large gold bullions serve as climbable decoration.

Train modelling: uses Mario Kart 64 Calamari Desert locomotive as base reference, borrows textures from MK7 version, aims for ~180 triangles, CI4 textures, real headlight with light-cone, and slightly extruded wheels for 3-D look.
development_findings.quote: Should we just take the Mario Kart 7 train? Maybe we use its textures but not the whole model…

development_findings.summary: Train will run a fixed loop every ~10 seconds; implementation waits for track collision to be finalised.
development_findings.quote: We can’t program the train yet because we need the collision baked for that.

development_findings.summary: Optimisation philosophy: prefers screen-space quads for coins to save RAM/DMEM, keeps textures CI4, batches by texture, focuses on raising skill-ceiling even if it complicates other hackers’ workflows.
development_findings.quote: I don’t really care about raising the skill floor, I care about raising the skill ceiling.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is fully ‘in cowboy mode’: wearing a cowboy hat on stream and only watching cowboy TV shows (e.g., Westworld) while working for immersion.
context_findings.quote: My dedication to the cowboy theme is still big, I started only watching cowboy TV shows while working on this.

context_findings.summary: Expresses frustration that his newest YouTube video (on course-code) is under-performing despite high click-through and watch-time; theorises algorithm suppression because it isn’t typical Mario 64 content.
context_findings.quote: It doesn’t make any sense… the algorithm probably saw it’s not Mario 64 and didn’t show it to my audience.

context_findings.summary: Design philosophy: values intrinsic motivation in games; criticises modern open-world ‘fetch-quest’ design (e.g., Zelda TotK) and extrinsic reward loops.
context_findings.quote: Everywhere you go there’s some extrinsic reward… it just feels like I’m an ant collecting sugar.

biobak.summary: Spotted that decorative spheres were half-sunken; Kaze adjusted model heights.
Will redo the 64 logo texture on the train to remove artefacts.
biobak.quote: Do not worry, I will make it better later.

key_stories.title: Building the Town Layout
key_stories.summary: Kaze tours chat around the near-finished block-out of the Wild-West hub, naming each store and explaining planned interactions.
key_stories.challenge: Need a coherent, humorous western town that supports multiple objectives.
key_stories.process: Lists each building, decides on gimmicks (hat store, tumbleweed seller, chain-chomp pen, etc.).
key_stories.outcome: Concrete layout committed; next streams will fill interiors and NPC logic.
key_stories.key_quote: We move the cowboy slider all the way to the right—and then we keep going.

key_stories.title: Designing an N64-Friendly Train
key_stories.summary: Unsure whether to rip the Calamari Desert model or custom-build, Kaze mixes references, fights Photoshop to make a ‘64’ logo, and sizes the train until it looks right beside Mario.
key_stories.challenge: Create visually appealing locomotive within strict triangle/texture limits.
key_stories.process: Reference MK64 & MK7 models, build in Blender (~182 tris), CI4 textures, extrude wheels, plan headlight & car.
key_stories.outcome: Locomotive finished; code will follow once track collision baked.
key_stories.key_quote: I think the train shape is good so far—now it needs the bumper at the front.

key_stories.title: Algorithm Anxiety
key_stories.summary: Kaze notices his favourite new video is ‘doing terrible’ despite strong metrics and hypothesises YouTube mis-categorisation.
key_stories.challenge: Low initial views threaten morale and revenue.
key_stories.process: Opens analytics on stream, discusses CTR/watch-time, predicts 24-hour rebound.
key_stories.outcome: Decides to wait and see; good clip for creator-struggle angle.
key_stories.key_quote: Right now it’s doing poorly, but in 24 hours it’s going to do insanely well.
